notes: The Suzuki F6A (SOHC/DOHC) and K6A engines are the 'LS of Kei Cars'. Turbos, injectors, and sensors often interchange. The Autozam AZ-1 actually uses a mid-mounted Suzuki F6A engine, sharing many parts with the Alto Works and Cappuccino.

The Honda Beat's E07A engine is a high-revving version of the standard Acty truck engine. While the Beat has individual throttle bodies (MTREC), the block and many internals are shared with the humble Acty and Today. Acty parts are much cheaper.

The JB-DET 4-cylinder turbo engine from the Copen is a gem. It can be swapped into the lighter Mira (L700) chassis for a 'sleeper' build. Suspension parts (coilovers) often interchange between the Copen and Mira.

Watch out for bolt patterns! The Cappuccino and AZ-1 use the older 4x114.3 pattern, while the Beat uses the common 4x100. Cappuccino owners often swap to Swift GTi hubs or use adapters to run 4x100 wheels.

The JB-DET is a rare 660cc 4-cylinder turbo engine. It is incredibly smooth and rev-happy. Parts are harder to find than Suzuki engines, but the block is very stout. The turbo is tiny (RHF3) and runs out of breath quickly.

Almost ALL original Honda Beat ECUs suffer from leaking capacitors which damage the board. If your Beat has idle issues or won't start, check the ECU immediately. Rebuild services are available, or swap to a 'Sport' ECU.
The front brakes on the Cappuccino are small. You can upgrade to the larger vented rotors and calipers from the Suzuki Swift GTi (AA34S) or certain Alto Works models. Requires 14-inch wheels minimum.

Subaru used a supercharger (AMR300/AMR500) instead of a turbo for instant throttle response on their Kei cars. The EN07 engine is robust (cloverleaf block). The superchargers are popular for small engine projects (motorcycles, go-karts).
